discoveredAssets: localhost:80 - PHP Authentication Application (AUTH 03) - Apache 2.4.25 + PHP 5.6.40 - Port 80 - Login form with username/password fields

targets.objective: Test login form for authentication vulnerabilities including SQL injection, brute force resistance, default credentials, session management flaws, CSRF protection, error message information disclosure, and POST-based authentication bypass. Verify if successful login leads to protected endpoints or if authorization is properly enforced.
targets.rationale: Single entry point to the application with outdated PHP (5.6.40) and Apache (2.4.25) versions. Form-based authentication is primary attack surface. No error messages returned on failed login suggests potential for vulnerability exploitation. Need to verify if login is vulnerable to injection attacks, credential attacks, or if it reveals additional application endpoints upon successful authentication.

keyFindings: [CRITICAL] PHP 5.6.40 is end-of-life and contains multiple known security vulnerabilities
[CRITICAL] Apache 2.4.25 contains known security vulnerabilities - consider upgrading to 2.4.58 or later
[HIGH] No HTTPS available - authentication credentials transmitted in cleartext over HTTP
[HIGH] No error messages returned on login failure - information disclosure prevention but also prevents legitimate user feedback
[MEDIUM] No robots.txt or sitemap.xml - potential for undiscovered endpoints if successful authentication occurs
[MEDIUM] Static directory browsing disabled (403 Forbidden) - proper configuration
[LOW] Theme references 'Springfield' (Simpsons) suggesting application is intentionally vulnerable for training/testing purposes
